title: Paystubs & Taxes
description: Understand your earnings, mandatory deductions, and why your take-home pay is different.

content.title: Gross vs. Net Pay
content.text: Your 'Gross Pay' is the total amount you earned before any deductions. Your 'Net Pay' (or take-home pay) is what actually lands in your bank account after the government takes its share for taxes and social programs.

content.title: The 'Big Three' Deductions
content.text: Almost every paycheck in Canada has three mandatory deductions: 1. Income Tax (Federal and Provincial), 2. CPP (Canada Pension Plan) for your retirement, and 3. EI (Employment Insurance) which protects you if you lose your job.

content.title: Year-to-Date (YTD)
content.text: Your paystub will show a 'YTD' column. This is a running total of everything you have earned and all the taxes you have paid since January 1st of the current year. This section is very helpful for planning your year-end tax return.

quiz.question: What does 'Net Pay' refer to on your Canadian paystub?
options: The amount of tax you owe at the end of the year
The actual 'take-home' money deposited into your bank account
Your hourly wage multiplied by your hours
quiz.explanation: Net Pay is your final take-home pay after all mandatory deductions like taxes, CPP, and EI have been removed.

quiz.question: Which deduction provides you with temporary income if you are laid off from your job?
quiz.explanation: Employment Insurance (EI) is a mandatory deduction that provides temporary financial assistance to workers who lose their job through no fault of their own.
